text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
IRM 10.8.11.1.1.1.(5), Scope - Updated the requirement to show IRM 10.8.1 has precedence over the IRM 10.8 series and the Security Requirements Checklists.

IRM 10.8.11.3.3, AU - Audit and Accountability, AU - 2 Audit Events changed to Event Logging, AU - 15 Alternate Audit Capability is withdrawn, AU - 16 Cross-Organizational Auditing changed to Cross-Organizational Audit Logging to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.
10.8.11.3.3.3, AU - 5 Response to Audit Processing Failures changed to Response to Audit Process Failures to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.
IRM 10.8.11.3.3.4, AU - 6 Audit Review, Analysis, and Reporting changed to Audit Record Review, Analysis, and Reporting to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.
IRM 10.8.11.3.4, CA - Security Assessment, and Authorization changed to Assessment, Authorization, and Monitoring to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.

IRM 10.8.11.3.5, CM - Conﬁguration Management, CM - 4 Security Impact Analysis changed to Impact Analysis, and CM - 12 Information Location, CM - 13 Data Action Mapping, CM - 14 Signed Components were added to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.
IRM 10.8.11.3.6, CP - Contingency Planning, CP - 5 Contingency Plan Update was withdrawn to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.

IRM 10.8.11.3.7, IA - Identiﬁcation and Authentication, IA - 10 Adaptive Identiﬁcation and Authentication changed to Adaptive Authentication, IA - 11 Reauthentication changed to Re-authentication, and IA - 12 Identity Prooﬁng was added to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.
IRM 10.8.11.3.11, PE - Physical Environmental Protection changed to Physical and Environmental Protection to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.
IRM 10.8.11.3.13, PM - Program Management was added to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.
IRM 10.8.11.3.15, PT - Personally Identiﬁable Information Processing and Transparency was added to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.
IRM 10.8.11.3.16, RA - Risk Assessment was renumbered from 10.8.11.3.14.
IRM 10.8.11.3.16.1, RA - 5 Vulnerability Scanning was changed Vulnerability Monitoring and Scanning to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.
10.8.11.3.17, SA – System and Services Acquisition was renumbered from 10.8.11.3.15.
10.8.11.3.18, SC – Systems and Communications Protection, changed to System and Protection to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.

IRM 10.8.11.3.18.23, SC - 35 Honeyclients was changed to External Malicious Code Identiﬁcation to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.

IRM 10.8.11.3.19, SI - System and Information Integrity, SI - 9 was withdrawn, SI - 12 Information Output Handling and Retention was changed to Information Management and Retention and SI - 18 Personally Identiﬁable Information Quality Operations, SI - 19 De-Identiﬁcation, SI - 20 Tainting, SI - 21 Information Refresh, SI - 22 Information Diversity, SI - 23 Information Fragmentation were added to align with NIST SP 800-53 Rev 5.

.Exhibit 10.8.11-3 References was updated to add the National Institute of Standards and Technology SP and Treasury Publication version and published dates.
Editorial changes made throughout the IRM for clarity. Reviewed and updated plain language, grammar, titles, website addresses, legal references and IRM references.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

This IRM supplements IRM 10.8.1, Information Technology (IT) Security Policy and Guidance; IRM Information Technology (IT) Security, IT Security Roles and Responsibilities. IRM 10.8.11, dated August 10, 2021 is superseded. This IRM incorporates Interim Guidance Memorandum 10-0122-0002, Splunk Enterprise Checklists, issued March 3, 2022.
AUDIENCE

IRM 10.8.11 shall be distributed to all personnel responsible for overseeing, managing, and implementing security for IRS information and information systems. The Application Security Policy will consist will not be limited to, agency deﬁned requirements, authoritative guidance, legislative mandates, and standards. This policy applies to all employees, contractors, and vendors of the IRS.

providers, that use or operate systems that store, process, or transmit IRS information or connect to an IRS network or system: (
) Policy Owner: Chief Information Officer (
) Program Owner: Cybersecurity Threat Response and Remediation (an zation within Cybersecurity) (
) Program Goals: Cybersecurity Policy is responsible for the development maintenance of IRS’s enterprise information technology security policies. IRM

Series provides the minimum-security requirements to protect the conﬁdentiality, integrity, and availability of data processed on IRS systems. IRMs are developed in accordance with applicable laws, policies, federal lations, Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Department of the Directives (TDs), National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) cations, and the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA). (
) IRM

deﬁnes security controls for application programs. An is a software program that is hosted by an information system and is to perform a speciﬁc function directly for the user or, in some cases, for another application. Application programs can be executed without access system control, monitoring, or administrative privileges. (
) IRM
is part of the Security, Privacy, and Assurance policy family, Part
Series for IRS Information Technology Cybersecurity. (

) This IRM applies to all IRS information and systems, which include IRS pro- duction, development, test, and contractor systems. For information systems that store, process, or transmit classiﬁed national security information, refer IRM
, Classiﬁed National Security Information (NSI), for additional dures for protecting classiﬁed information. (

Unless approved by the CIO, given the associated security challenges, lack of security solutions and high implementation cost, the use of emerging gies that have not been evaluated by the federal government for their national security impacts is prohibited. (E.O. 13960 Sec 2 (c), Sec 3 (b); 44 USC 3551
10.8 Information Technology (IT) Security
) For a list of Organizational Common Controls (OCC), contact Security Risk Management (SRM). (

) Security Requirements Checklists: a. Security Requirements Checklists, if accompanying this IRM, serve as the secure conﬁguration benchmark and are developed in accordance with NIST Special Publication (SP)

, National Checklist for IT Products: Guidelines for Checklist Users and Developers. b. IRMs with accompanying checklists contain a checklist with general security requirements (e.g., Defense Information Systems Agency Security Requirements Guide (SRG)), as well as checklists with or technology speciﬁc requirements (e.g., Security Technical tion Guides (STIGs), Center for Internet Security (CIS) Benchmarks). the event a platform or technology speciﬁc checklist is not available, general security requirements checklist shall be used (e.g., Database (General), Operating System (General), Router (General)). c. Security Requirements Checklists shall be used in addition to the ments within this IRM. d. In the event of a conﬂict between a checklist and this IRM, excluding Treasury’s deﬁned requirements, the requirement(s) from the checklist shall take precedence. e. Implementation of Security Requirements Checklists is required (CM - f. Refer to the Security Requirements Checklist exhibit for additional guidance. (
) In the event there is a discrepancy between this IRM, the Checklists and
, IRM
has precedence, unless the security in this IRM are more restrictive or otherwise noted. (

) This IRM establishes the minimum baseline security policy and for all IRS IT assets in order to: a. Protect the critical infrastructure and assets of the IRS against attacks that exploit IRS assets. b. Prevent unauthorized access to IRS assets. c. Enable IRS IT computing environments to meet the security of this IRM and support the business needs of the organization. (
) It is acceptable to conﬁgure settings to be more restrictive than those in this IRM. (
) To conﬁgure less restrictive requirements requires a risk-based decision. to the Risk Acceptance and Risk-Based Decisions section within this IRM additional guidance. (
) All IRS information systems and applications shall be compliant with orders (E.O.s), Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Federal Security Modernization Act of
(FISMA), National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Department of Homeland Security (DHS), of the Treasury, and IRS guidelines as they apply.

Security Requirements Checklists: a. Security Requirements Checklists, if accompanying this IRM, serve as the secure conﬁguration benchmark and are developed in accordance with NIST Special Publication (SP)

, National Checklist Program for IT Products: Guidelines for Checklist Users and Developers. b. IRMs with accompanying checklists contain a checklist with general security requirements (e.g., Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA) Security Requirements Guide (SRG)), as well as checklists with platform or technology speciﬁc requirements (e.g., Security Technical Implementa- tion Guides (STIGs), Center for Internet Security (CIS) Benchmarks). In the event a platform or technology speciﬁc checklist is not available, the general security requirements checklist shall be used (e.g., Database (General), Operating System (General), Router (General)). c. Security Requirements Checklists shall be used in addition to the ments within this IRM. d. In the event of a conﬂict between a checklist and this IRM, excluding Treasury’s deﬁned requirements, the requirement(s) from the checklist shall take precedence. e. Implementation of Security Requirements Checklists is required (CM -
). f. Refer to the Security Requirements Checklist exhibit for additional guidance.
) IRM

, Information Technology (IT) Security, IT Security Roles and Re- sponsibilities, deﬁnes IRS-wide roles and responsibilities related to IRS information and computer security, and is the authoritative source for such in- formation.
